Has anyone considered a Zulip redesign to be like Discord’s new light theme?

https://blog.discord.com/light-theme-redeemed-c541b7ab13e9

image.png https://miro.medium.com/max/4050/1*iwfLW4rnn6U-mlUQpmBAfg.png
@DerickZhou what specifically about that design are you excited about?
We definitely are considering design changes to the message feed in the coming months.
But that does seem like a nicely done article about their thought process.

@Tim Abbott

  • the reduced color palette where white and grey are the primary colors
  • less use of “color bars as content dividers”. what I mean is today there’s a lot of use of colored bars to be used as dividers which becomes distracting. Eg “Discord >> Redesign to be like discord” has a background colored bar used as a divider. Replacing this with something more like the “—- yesterday—-today—-“ in Zulip as a divider of context discussions is less distracting & more pleasing
  • simplified. Eg just in the chat input field, I see an icon for : smiley, text formatting, attachment, video. Eyeball, drafts. On Discord, only 1/2 of those options are present.

On the simplified topic, another example is when I click REPLY, why does it displays the topic of “design > redesign to be like discoed”. Why display that? If I click REPLY it should be assumed it’s to this topic. There appears from my, granted limited insight, lots of visual either content or artifacts that could just be removed from the current design.

Another example is why display at the top there’s 14k users.

Now I say this all with love for Zulip. I do firmly believe it solves for problems that other solutions do not. So please don’t take my comments as being negative. Just supportive.

@Tim Abbott
Another thing that is good about Discord light theme:

  • is the focus on the feed (being in white) and the de-emphasised focus on the far left and right columns (in grey)
  • the window padding is increased. Note: I'm note saying more overall padding, I'm simply saying that at the bottom/left/right of the window in Discord there is more padding making it easier to click the "Send" button so that it doesn't feel so cramped against the bottom of the browser window
  • on the topic of removing visual noise, if I've already selected the #design -> "redesign to be like discord" Stream to be my focus, why in the feed area does it repeat saying that I'm in the "design ->" stream. This seems like visual noise that can be removed

This is a pet peeve of mine, too. We don't need "design" right on top of "design". @Yash ✨ is this still on your radar?

image.png
Personally I find the 14k users as a helpful reminder of the size of your audience.
It's the second one that I'd eliminate.

Personally I find the 14k users as a helpful reminder of the size of your audience.

I see now that you were responding to @DerickZhou here...I was a bit confused.
I wonder if both @DerickZhou and @HankW are commenting on the interleaved stream views.
@Tim Abbott Yes, from the image above ... remove the 2nd (bottom blue) "design > ..."

That's a beautiful design. It's funny because everyone seems to be so focused on dark mode lately and they're not focusing on building good "light" themes and designs as much anymore.

Few things that stand out from a design perspective to me:

The bigger bolder fonts are definitely in. Notably Apple is pivoting towards bigger and bolder fonts as well with macOS Big Sur and iOS 14 https://www.apple.com/macos/big-sur-preview/ I usually follow Apple when it comes to design trends like this, especially since so many people use Macs now, matching the UI/UX elements for the next version of mac/iOS helps keep the apps looking like they belong by following similar design principles.

I also like the rounded user icons, and the white space utilization is pretty good although maybe a little too much in some splaces. There's definitely some crowding in Zulip's design where a few extra pixels of padding could go along way.

Things I don't like about this design is there's too many different similar yet contrasting shades of grey. I definitely prefer Zulip's more effective utilization of just plain white.

If there is anything we could borrow from this from a design perspective, I'd say circular icons, bigger and bolder fonts, and increasing our padding / spacing (not much, just a few pixels in some cases).
https://twist.com/ Also has a nice design. Screenshots on homepage
https://youtu.be/gXEjBaAbshA
Re:Twist: More circular icons, good white space / padding, and bigger bolder fonts.
image.png https://cdn.zapier.com/storage/photos/ada4e111437c9bc85e8b052d09eaeeea.png
@Trent Lapinski do you like twist UI or not? I like it but I feel like the padding is just a bit too much (not enough info density. But that’s an easy change)

Kind of boring if I'm going to be honest. It feels too much like e-mail which I don't like. I do like its modern look and feel, but yeah they over do the padding, and it has a Facebook or Asana look to it that I'm not a huge fan of. It isn't a bad design, just not the design decisions I would make personally.

The things that I like in common between the Discord light theme and Twist is

  • less use of color
  • simplified design (less elements on the screen)
  • slight increase in padding (but not much)
  • slight increase in font size (but not much)
  • no redundant info on the screen (like how we duplicate the title bar of the stream name)
  • a focus on the news feed (white news feed / grey sidebars)
@Trent Lapinski @Tim Abbott curious to hear your take on what I like in their design

Reminiscent of potential from #design > User Feedback. There was this discussion and resulting PR about removing the stream redundancy. But I honestly think we should just remove the pentagon shape, as Steve suggested there, and just put a colored > like we have in the topic popover menu and mention syntax.
Leave the navbar out of it, unlike the aforementioned PR, and just drive home that #stream>topic syntax
I feel like that syntax isn't all that discoverable. Instead, in plan view, you would have a # with the stream and a > with the topic on the front page of every discussion.
(Or at least have this change be part of a transition to something more permanent. Just as a means to get rid of some of the noise.)
Here's a quick dev tools hack cause I actually got curious what this would look like.
Wouldn’t the simpler and cleaner route be to just dynamically change what’s shown in the search bar to be whatever #Stream & topic your viewing @Wyatt Hoodes

I’d also say the setting (gear icon) should be hidden under a menu and not a prominent visual element which is always displayed

Wouldn’t the simpler and cleaner route be to just dynamically change what’s shown in the search bar to be whatever #Stream & topic your viewing Wyatt Hoodes

https://youtu.be/gXEjBaAbshA

very very cool
I saw that Twist has a function that I proposed some time ago #feedback > Solved/closed topic

very usefull

Tim Abbott said:

Interleaved views are valuable in contexts that don't always match chat.zulip.org. E.g. they're great when traffic is low and you want to leave Zulip open on a side monitor and be able to see new messages come in without having to click into the window at all.

So much this. Flowdock didn't have an interleaved view, but displayed one flow (stream) at a time. I so much wished for a firehose where I could keep an eye on what's happening globally without having to esc + a (equivalent of N) all the time.

Don't overlook the value of All messages.
Oh, and don't forget that search result is an interleaved view too.

But I get the redundancy argument... So how about this:

Restyle the recipient bar to # stream > topic, with big bold colored # and > (as in the navbar/Wyatts screenshot). This is default (All messages, search result).

When narrowed down to stream, change it to > topic (still colored >), and we have the # stream in the navbar.

When narrowed to topic, lose the recipient bar (need to figure out what to do with the mute button), and put # stream > topic into the navbar. Something similar can be done to PMs.

The links in the navbar should probably be changed, so one can click on # stream when in topic narrow and go to stream narrow.

Good or bad idea?
I think it's a little overkill to remove the recipient bar. Topics can have arbitrary length and there's also the edit, the edit spinner, error and the date that are on that block.

@Yash ✨ Yeah, I know it would require some thinking about where to put those things (where message buttons are perhaps), but if we're moving stream into the navbar because of redundancy, it makes sense to move topic too. It makes sense that if you're looking at a thing (stream, topic, whatever), it's in the navbar.

If we managed to get the stream description in there, the length of topics shouldn't be a problem.
Stream description is important to display in the navbar for new members to understand its use and to be used as pinned stream announcements.

Aman Agrawal said:

Stream description is important to display in the navbar for new members to understand its use and to be used as pinned stream announcements.

One flaw with this logic is that once a user has read the description, they will rarely look at it again.
After that it's just extra noise in regular use
The current stream was important enough information to duplicate to the navbar, I'd say that current topic is of equal importance.
Yeah, I'd probably keep the topic bar -- there's UI on it, and also having a consistent algorithm for "When was this?" of scanning up the right column is valuable and removing it would break that.

Linking #14778 which was a complaint about not having the topic in the navbar.
And I'm thinking... the real problem here?
It's this: "that is often ambiguous when scrolling."

I got a question: Why was the stream name put in the navbar? Is there any argument for putting stream name there that doesn't apply to topic too?

We got some prime screen realestate up there, and I think that Wesleys point about current topic being more valuable information than stream description is valid. And I think that his point that one is more interested in the stream description in stream narrows is quite good too.

I know that it's a bit far fetched, but losing the recipient bars in topic narrows would go a long way towards being "more like Discord".

I don't think "more like Discord" is actually the goal; the goal is to make the design nicer.

For context, the stream description (or something conceptually similar like "pinned messages") in that top navbar area was the second most requested feature in Zulip for a long time. My feeling is that it's something that's important for administrators but less so to end users who aren't trying to get information out to subscribers. I don't think we'll want to remove that, though we could of course consider other designs that fit the topic at the top (e.g. using 2 lines).

My thinking is we want the topic to stay in the recipient bar to preserve that as a consistent part of the experience (regardless of what type of view you're in, you just look up from the current message to the next recipient bar and you get the date and the thread).

So, even though there's a limit to how close we can get to discord because our model is different and having the recipient bar stick right near the end of the navbar is approximately as good as having it be a part of the navbar, we could try out something where it directly attaches to the navbar....
... but I don't think there's an immediate need for it. Kill FRB first.

I don't think we want to drop the stream description that's there, and replacing the stream name field with topic names would not make sense since topic names tend to be longer / more complex.

Having the description be always visible is beneficial for a great many reasons, including broad stuff like: consistency, ease for new users, a more descriptive theme for stream contents than just the stream name, as well as small stuff: links, markdown content etc

I don't think "more like Discord" is actually the goal; the goal is to make the design nicer.

I was using "more like Discord" as a shorthand for "nicer design" and "easier to understand for new users".

My thinking is we want the topic to stay in the recipient bar to preserve that as a consistent part of the experience (regardless of what type of view you're in, you just look up from the current message to the next recipient bar and you get the date and the thread).

But I could make the same argument for stream name? As it is now, when I'm in all messages, I need to scan upwards, but for stream/topic narrows I should look in the navbar (if we remove it from the recipient bar there). In PMs, when I narrow to a person, it has that persons name in the navbar. I think it would be more consistent if the navbar reflected that I'm actually in a topic narrow, rather than being equivalent to a stream narrow.

And I think that if we assume that people understand why we remove stream names in stream narrow, it would make just as much sense to them if we removed topic in topic narrow..

I personally would like to keep the interleaved view, it's helpful to go through stuff when coming back after a period.
I was thinking to work on improving the message UI along with the bit to remove stream name when narrowed on a stream if someone is not working already on it.
I think there's a PR for that idea, though there's some debate on how to do it.

  2. No need to have right side bar, as it is duplicated and available on left side also. So PMs and Users can be accessible from same space. New user can be also invited from here.   6. Users can be invited and new stream can be created from '+' icon beside search icon. So removing links to give more space and cleanliness to left sidebar.
  7. Adding three dot action menu next to search icon on top right for actions on stream same as it is available on left side bar.
  8. Other UI functionality like mouse hover, actions, message body etc remain as it is.

Discord doesn't support threading (within a channel). Thus its UI mechanics are pretty different from Zulip. Also Discord is optimized for public gaming chat, not serious discussions at work. So Discord's requirements are somewhat different.

Slack is a much better comparison. Its architecture and use case are very similar to Zulip.

MS Teams is also very similar to Zulip, but personally I haven't seen "forum" style discussions happening much in Teams. Perhaps it is because the UI does not provide good mechanisms for keeping track of many different threads. Slack's UI really does that well.

Slack offers a selection of ready-made colour schemes to choose from, which is a nice feature, since users tend to like the ability to personalize their view.

Somewhat related (general UX): I occasionally access Zulip on my phone. I prefer the browser version, because it is full-featured. My only problem is that the buttons are a bit small for a touch screen. In my view, adapting their size to fit grubby fingers would render the need for a native app obsolete.

@Plankter Thanks for the feedback. In the early days of our mobile app, I tended to use the browser app for the same reason you do. I now mostly use the native mobile app, but there are still times where I wish we had invested more in making the browser experience nicer on mobile. We had a couple folks make some nice tweaks in 2020, and when anybody steps up to fix mobile web bugs or usability issues, we are usually pretty receptive to patches.

Most of the mobile web annoyances are about either controls being too small for the thumbs or other device-specific things, but there are some possible fixes that would benefit the desktop experience for people who like to tile windows.

So I hope somebody reading this gets inspired.
A native app will never be obsolete; the webapp on mobile can't do push notifications (etc.). But I would love to see work on making mobile web a bit nicer.

To address some of the questions you brought up in the video:

  • Our main scrollbar is on the browser’s right so that users with large screens have the entire browser window as a target area where they can use the scroll wheel or touchpad scroll gestures. Visually moving the scrollbar without breaking this would require some kind of kludge that listens for scroll events and manually translates them in code to scrolling movement; such emulation inevitably results in laggy awkward behavior that feels much worse than the platform’s native scrolling.
  • The Zulip logo in the top-left corner is customizable, and we expect organizations to replace it with their own logo, but it would be reasonable to streamline the default logo we use there.
  • The multiple new-message buttons are an effort to nudge new users toward keeping the discussion organized. There’s a concern, for example, that if starting a new topic were to take more clicks or be less discoverable than replying to an existing topic, it would become much more common for new users to randomly append new discussions to unrelated topics. There’s room for different ideas here; we’d need to do user testing to be sure.

Hey, sorry to be slow to jump into this one! I spent yesterday going through some threads that are a little less involved. :) I really appreciate the work from Vlad driving the discussion, and the thoughts/feedback everyone has been sharing! I think there are a lot of good ideas. To avoid writing one giant essay, I'll post a few messages with my thoughts on different aspects of the design.

In general, I like the overall visual direction -- it looks a lot cleaner!

Top area

I really like the rearrangement of the top area, which gets rid of the dead space above the user list. I had been imagining that we'd put the search box above the user list when we split it off from the stream description (#20163), but I think this is a better approach.

We can discuss (perhaps in a separate thread) whether it's important to have the stream user count and description at the top. I think we could plausibly remove it with a combination of:

  1. Showing the info in a tooltip when hovering over the name of the stream in the top bar.
  2. Making the info easier to find in the menus (e.g. at the moment, subscriber count is shown in the left panel but not the right panel).
  3. Implementing pinned topics (#19483), which will be a good way to share important links and other info.

Right sidebar

I personally find the right sidebar distracting and not super useful in a large org like CZO, and I'm looking forward to the option to hide it (#19927). (Though perhaps it'll be more useful with the work Yash RE is doing in #20072. :)) Even so, I don't think the fully monochromatic look is great (at least as a default option), though we could play with more muted colors, especially for the orange. We should keep in mind that:

  1. In a smaller org (and on CZO after #20072), the orange helps distinguish from offline users. Currently on CZO, those users are always off-screen.
  2. It's nice to have consistency between the right sidebar colors and left sidebar colors for PMs, where the green vs. orange vs. grey is already helpful.

As a note, we've had some discussion about optionally showing profile pics in the right sidebar (#19999), as a user option. So it would be good for the same status indicator colors to work well superimposed on a profile pic as well.

I feel like the current UI where they are very distinct helps with identifying which streams to read, but it may be fine to have it be more subtle.
  2. For PMs, I'm hoping it'll work well to put them into a separate section, as described in #19447. That way it'll take fewer clicks to get to them, and it should be more discoverable for new users.

Message view

I don't have as much that's concrete to say on this one. I'd be open to playing with removing the vertical stream-colored bars on the left, and making the unread line on the left more thin and subtle.

I'm not sure what's best for the stream/topic bars. We could play with removing the stream name, but I think even as it is users sometimes find it confusing what stream they are looking at and/or composing to. If we go that route, we may need to make the stream name in the top bar stand out more.

For the compose box, Zulip has a long history of new users finding it hard to figure out how to send a message. We only stopped hearing that after the change (made in 2021) that introduced the long "Message stream > topic" button. So while I think the current three-button setup is far from perfect, I think it'll be a whole mini-project to figure out how to improve it without re-introducing confusion for new users. And of course, as I think Vlad mentioned, having a single compose button requires other changes to the compose experience. (I would love to see "Convert replies between stream and private messages #3409" regardless.)

Removing and hiding buttons

  1. It's probably fine to hide the "Subscribe to more streams" link in the bottom left; we can to some user testing to make sure folks can find the "+" next to Streams.
  2. If we remove the "Invite more users" link in the bottom right, I wonder if we should add a "+" button next to the "Users" heading to parallel the streams? Not sure.
  3. Making the filter/plus/search buttons hidden except on hover seems like another good candidate for user testing.
  4. I've always felt that the keyboard button looks untethered/out of place. I understand that we want to make it easy to figure out that Zulip has awesome keyboard shortcuts, but it would be great to explore alternatives for how to do that.
